'Quantitative phase contrast microscopy', quantitative phase microscopy or just
phase microscopy are the collective names for a group of microscopy methods
which quantifies the phase shift that occurs when light waves passes through a
more optically dense object.

Translucent objects, like a living human cell, absorb or scatter small amounts
of light. This makes translucent objects difficult to observe in ordinary light
microscopes. Such objects do, however, induce a phase shift that can be observed
using either a Zernike or a Nomarski phase contrast microscope. Unfortunately,
both microscopy methods visualize phase shifts by transforming phase shift
gradients into intensity variations. These intensity variations are mixed with
other intensity variations, making it difficult to extract quantitative
information from conventional phase contrast microscopy images. {{cite journal

The principal methods for measuring and visualizing phase shifts include
ptychography and various types of holographic microscopy methods such as digital
holographic microscopy, holographic interference microscopy and digital in-line
holographic microscopy. Common to these methods is that an interference pattern
(hologram) is recoded by a digital image sensor. From the recorded interference
pattern, a so called phase shift image or phase image is numerically created by
a computer algorithm. {{cite journal
| author=Myung K. Kim title=Principles and techniques of digital holographic
| microscopy journal=SPIE Reviews volume=1 pages=018005 year=2010
| doi=10.1117/6.0000006
|bibcode = 2010SPIER...1a8005K }}
